data.name: Time Conversion: 12s and 24s
data.description:
Complete the functions _12to24 and _24to12 to convert time between 12 hour, and 24 hour notations. For the purpose of this kata, the following formats will be used for both input and output: -- -- 12 hour notation:
`[h]h:mm[:ss] pp` - `[h]h` - Between one and two digits representing the hour. e.g. '2', '02', '11' - `mm` - Two digits representing the minutes. e.g. '02', '14' - `[ss]` - Two [optional] digits representing the seconds. e.g. '08', '36', '59' - `pp` - A two character representation of the period (either 'am' or 'pm'). - `:` - A colon separates each existing numeric group Examples: `1:24 pm`, `12:59 AM`, `04:01pm`, `07:10:15 pm`, `11:00:00AM`. Note: The maximum valid time in this notation is `12:59:59` regardless of period. More information about 12 hour time can be found here. -- -- 24 hour notation:
`hh:mm[:ss]` - `hh` - Two digits representing the hour. e.g. '02', '11', '23' - `mm` - Two digits representing the minutes. e.g. '06', '29' - `[ss]` - Two [optional] digits representing the seconds. e.g. '08', '36', '59' - `:` - A colon separates each numeric group Examples: `00:00`, `02:13:14`, `01:05`, `19:26`. Note: The maximum valid time in this notation is `23:59:59`.
Note: Midnight is occasionally displayed as `24:00:00`. For the sake of consistency, in this kata we will use the more common `00:00:00`. More information about 24 hour time can be found here. -- -- The test cases for this kata are in three formats: - `Valid Strings` A random number of randomly generated time strings known to be valid will be tested against both conversion functions. - `Invalid Strings` A random selection of time strings known to be invalid will be tested against both conversion functions. (These should all throw 'error'). - `Format Preservation` A random number of randomly generated time strings will be converted to their opposite format, converted back to their original format, and tested against the orginal. -- -- Notes: - Invalid inputs must always throw 'error'. - Spacing and case may vary in your inputs, but both will be disregarded in the official tests. String.prototype.normalize has been provided to handle this if you wish to use it.
